column2: Proportion of girls and women aged 15-49 years who have undergone female genital mutilation/cutting, by age
Number of newly recorded cases of girls and women who have undergone female genital mutilation/cutting by age at which mutilation/cutting occurred.

Female genital mutilation/cutting (FGM/C) refers to all procedures involving partial or total removal of the female external genitalia or other injury to the female genital organs for non-medical reasons"" (World Health Organization
column3: Eliminating Female Genital Mutilation - An interagency statement
column17: p.4). The World Health Organisation defines the four types of female genital mutilation as follows -

National metadata: Type 1 - Partial or total removal of the clitoral glans (the external and visible part of the clitoris
column2: which is a sensitive part of the female genitals
column3: with the function of providing sexual pleasure to the woman)
column4: and/or the prepuce/clitoral hood (the fold of skin surrounding the clitoral glans).

National metadata: Type 2 - Partial or total removal of the clitoral glans and the labia minora (the inner folds of the vulva)
column2: with or without removal of the labia majora (the outer folds of skin of the vulva).

National metadata: Type 3 - (Often referred to as infibulation). Narrowing of the vaginal opening with the creation of a covering seal. The seal is formed by cutting and repositioning the labia minora
column2: or labia majora. The covering of the vaginal opening is done with or without removal of the clitoral prepuce/clitoral hood and glans (Type I FGM).

National metadata: Type 4 - All other harmful procedures to the female genitalia for non-medical purposes

column2: 1. Values between 1-7 are rounded to 5. All other values are rounded to the nearest 5. 2. Individuals refers to all patients in the reporting period where FGM was identified or a procedure for FGM was undertaken.  Each patient is only counted once.
Number of individuals the NHS has interacted with where FGM was identified
